node.excerpt: We are now a couple of weeks out from the GPT-3 release by Open AI. I have consumed summaries and reflections by people that I respect and…

frontmatter.title: This was not written by GPT-3
frontmatter.description: From my viewpoint, GPT-3 should not scare us. It is an opportunity.

node.excerpt: Below are some of my favourite articles/blog posts about racial justice by Black journalists and writers. The list will be constantly…

frontmatter.title: Black Lives Matter
frontmatter.description: I have a lot to say but now is not the time for my voice. Every day we should be amplifying and giving space to Black voices but especially now because the movement has more momentum than it has had since the 60s and 70s. Keep that energy going. Liberation happens collectively.

node.excerpt: Like all of us, I’ve been spending a lot of time online during the coronavirus pandemic. As companies announce permanent remote-first work…

frontmatter.title: The future of interaction: Tech vs the People
frontmatter.description: Like all of us, I have been spending a lot of time online during the coronavirus pandemic. As companies announce permanent remote-first work or pivot their strategies to increase online engagement, I have watched with great interest the multitude of "hot takes" that have overtaken my twitter feed.

node.excerpt: When I was first learning Golang, I didn’t think I would be using it in the workplace just 4 months later. I’m still learning the language…

frontmatter.title: Lessons from using self-learned Golang in the workplace
frontmatter.description: Just like applying skills from a degree to the workplace is different, so is applying self-learned skills. That’s why I wanted to take some time to share some of the ways my thinking shifted once I started using Go in a professional environment.
